thread.title: REM to go live on Facebook with the Guardian – send in your questions | Music
thread.title_full: REM to go live on Facebook with the Guardian – send in your questions | Music | The Guardian

posts.author: Guardian music
posts.title: REM to go live on Facebook with the Guardian – send in your questions | Music
posts.text:
This Friday, REM come to London! Not to play a reunion show, sadly, but to talk about their career and the 25th anniversary of their album Out of Time , which is getting the deluxe reissue treatment, also on Friday.
On 18 November, Michael Stipe and Mike Mills from the band will be in conversation with the Guardian’s John Harris, and we will stream the event live on our Facebook page . Stipe and Mills will also be taking your questions. So if there’s something you desperately want to ask them about the contrary career of one of the most unlikely superstar bands in pop history, email your question to: R.E.M.Ques@umusic.com .
REM on Out of Time at 25: ‘Being the voice of a generation is not a pretty place to be’ Read more 
As Michael Stipe told our own Michael Hann recently: “You can fuck with people if you’re gonna be contrarian. And we were always contrarian about it. We would go on stage and perform the four songs everyone knew. This was 1987. We would open the set with the four songs everyone knew, then – the real fans, you can stay. Everyone else go home, go drink somewhere else, go flirt somewhere else … But we were always contrarian, and we were always pushing ourselves to do things differently. To not have the same setlist every night, to not allow it to become a job. We were throwing marbles under our feet at every turn to try to trip ourselves, to try to not allow it to become quotidian. Is that the word? Uninteresting, mediocre, boring.”
This promises to be a fascinating event – especially because it is their first chance to speak publically about Donald Trump’s America. So tune in on Friday – Stipe and Mills take to the stage at 12.30pm – and see what they have to say about the life of REM and the state of the US.

thread.title: Who wears the pantsuits in Alabama? Clinton supporters found community in secret Facebook group
thread.title_full: Who wears the pantsuits in Alabama? Clinton supporters found community in secret Facebook group | AL.com

posts.author: Michelle Matthews | mmatthews@al.com
posts.title: Who wears the pantsuits in Alabama? Clinton supporters found community in secret Facebook group
posts.text:
On Election Day, they showed up wearing pantsuits.
For many women, it's already their daily work uniform. Others haven't worn one in years. Still others went out to buy one to mark the occasion. For the first time in American history, a woman was on the ballot as the Democratic candidate for president and, thanks to a movement that spread via social media, many women were adopting Hillary Clinton's penchant for pantsuits as they voted.
In Alabama, thousands of women posted photos of themselves, along with stories about what they were wearing, in a place where they could share such often-personal information, where they didn't have to worry than anyone would "troll" their post or say anything negative at all.
In Alabama, that place was a Facebook group that grew out of a 3-million-strong national group, Pantsuit Nation.
By Tuesday, the Alabama group had become a haven for the 7,000-plus women who had joined it in its first four days of existence. Throughout the day, the page was filled with photos of smiling women of all ages, proudly casting their vote for Clinton, sometimes accompanied by their significant others, their children, their friends and even by their late mothers and grandmothers, whose jewelry and other items they wore.
Not all of them wore pantsuits. Some wore all-white, in honor of the suffragettes who fought for the 19 th Amendment – and that's a big deal in Alabama, where most women know you just don't wear white after Labor Day, even if it's 90 degrees outside.
Later that evening, though, the excitement and optimism of the Alabama group had turned to shock, sorrow and anger, as the election results indicated that Clinton would not be the first female president after all. Over the next few days, though, the membership continued to grow – in just one week, it hit the 10,000-member mark – as women shared their thoughts and feelings with each other in a supportive environment.
Immediately, the members vowed to continue working together in the future, in some way.
"The best thing to happen as a result of this crazy election: This page," wrote one.
'Part of a community'
The secret group was the brainchild of Alabama native Amy LeePard, 36, who lives in Northport and works in higher education technology at the University of Alabama.
LeePard was inspired to create the group when she saw a member in the larger Pantsuit Nation group refer to herself as "a single blue dot in Alabama."
As "someone more progressive than my state as a whole," she said, she knows how "disenfranchising and silencing" that can be. "I know many people in this election have felt very isolated. I wanted to respond to that, to give them an opportunity to connect and know they're part of a community."
After she created the group on the Saturday morning before the election on Tuesday, she shared the new Alabama group in the larger Pantsuit Nation and started receiving 100 requests an hour for the rest of the day.
"It kept growing and growing," she said in an interview the evening of the election. "It was really amazing and intense to see how significant it's been for some people as a space for solidarity and community."
In the first few days, LeePard was surprised to read comments from members who "aren't afraid anymore," she said. "I didn't quite expect that. People are living with a lot more fear than I realized."
She has enjoyed the powerful stories of families that were shared with the group. "A sense of family and connection is so important to Southerners," she said.
The membership covers a lot of ground, she said, from atheists to Southern Baptists, from Republican voters who voted for a Democrat for the first time in this election to former Bernie Sanders supporters – and being female is not a prerequisite.
"The unifying thread is an acknowledgement that many of the things this election has emboldened are not okay, not messages we want to pass on to our children," she said. "This election has been very polarizing and distasteful in a way I don't think has been the case for a presidential election before."
The Facebook group she created "has been a space of positivity, encouragement, support and empowerment," she said. Friendships have been formed, issues discussed – sometimes heatedly – and plans have been made to become more formally organized.
Meanwhile, LeePard has watched in awe as the members governed themselves, which is exactly what she wanted. "It's important to me to be a facilitator, but not control what's happening," she said.
Making communities kinder, safer
LeePard's long day Tuesday started at the polls early in the morning – she voted at the community park she fought to save about a year ago – and ended when she took her 92-year-old maternal grandmother to vote and then out to dinner. "My Granny is one of my best friends," she said. "We've gone to vote together many times."
Her grandmother, who lives in Tuscaloosa, once felt disenfranchised herself. She grew up in Louisiana where, when she was a young voter, men would accompany women into the voting booth to make sure they voted the "right" way. As a result, she stopped voting for a long time.
"It's important to me that she votes, so our tradition is to vote together," LeePard said.
Her grandmother's 95-year-old sister lives in New Orleans. LeePard acknowledged that this could be the sisters' last presidential election, and she lamented the fact that they had to hear "such disgusting things" from Clinton's opponent (she doesn't say his name) throughout the campaign.
"It's unbelievable to them, and disheartening to me," she said. "It's sad to see their generation exposed" to such vulgarity and vitriol at the end of their lives.
Political activism runs in her blood. LeePard's paternal grandparents registered minority voters in Birmingham in the 1960s and "received threats for doing so," she said. "I appreciate what the right to vote means, what social justice means, regardless of who you vote for."
Several days after the election, LeePard said that there's been so much activity in the group's first full week of existence that it's difficult for her to keep up with it all. From the statewide group, other groups have been formed in North Alabama, Birmingham, Mobile and other areas. LeePard and other administrators have talked at length about how to move forward to heal communities while minimizing anger and divisiveness.
In the meantime, simple things can make a big difference, she said. "What we can change is how much we do in our communities. We can be kinder. There are many actions that we can take in our everyday lives and communities to create the kind of world we want our children to inherit, a world we want to live in where our friends and family members are safe."
Again and again in the group that's now "secret," meaning it can't be found by non-members, she said she's seeing "a lot of hope" in the members' posts, with "people wanting to do better." "It's not a matter of Republican or Democrat, it's how we agree to treat each other and take care of our neighbors." Making communities kinder and safer, she said, is "nonpartisan" and something every American should be working toward.
"This is an incredible opportunity to band together, support each other and recognize that action starts very locally."

thread.title: FTW: Ranking the NFL's most dysfunctional teams
thread.title_full: FTW: Ranking the NFL's most dysfunctional teams

posts.title: FTW: Ranking the NFL's most dysfunctional teams
posts.text:
FTW: Ranking the NFL's most dysfunctional teams Shocker: The Browns aren't last! Post to Facebook FTW: Ranking the NFL's most dysfunctional teams Shocker: The Browns aren't last!  //usat.ly/2fW4CVT   Join the Nation's Conversation To   FTW: Ranking the NFL's most dysfunctional teams Steven Ruiz , USATODAY 12:22   1 Shares 
(Photo: Ed Mulholland-USA TODAY Sports) 
The concept is simple: Which NFL teams are poorly run, and which are set up for long-term success. A lot of factors went into devising these rankings, including, but not limited to, front office competency, coaching longevity and future outlook, the direction of the franchise and whether a team has a franchise quarterback in place. With that said, let's get to the rankings, starting with the most functional team in the league… 1. New England Patriots 
Bill Belichick has made some questionable moves in the last year , but this team hasn't missed the postseason with a healthy Tom Brady since 2002. Nothing dysfunctional about that. 2. Seattle Seahawks 
The Seahawks have a smart general manager, a good head coach, a young franchise quarterback, and a cadre of defensive stars in the their prime and locked up to long-term deals. Seattle is going to be good for a very long time. FACEBOOK 29. San Diego Chargers 
The Chargers have a pretty good team on the field, but Mike McCoy is likely coaching his last season in San Diego and the team will probably leave the city in the offseason. Things could get ugly in December. 30. Jacksonville Jaguars 
Where do we start? Blake Bortles is getting called out by teammates . Gus Bradley is statistically one of the worst coaches ever . And now the team is selling their opponents' merchandise at the stadium . Your thoughts, Jaguars fans? View the GIF 31. Indianapolis Colts 
Do you know how incompetent the brain trust of a team has to be to squander Andrew Lucks' career? There's a reason why Colts fans refer to coach Chuck Pagano, GM Ryan Grigson and owner Jim Irsay as "The Three Stooges." 32. New York Jets 
The quarterback who held out for months is awful. The coach has lost control of the locker room. The best players on the team don't even bother to show up for team meetings , even when there's cake. The highest-paid player on the team is old and doesn't try. And the team's cap situation is troubling. Other than that, the Jets are in pretty good shape. Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/2fW4CVT Most Popular

thread.title: How many ads do NFL fans avoid with RedZone?
thread.title_full: How many ads do NFL fans avoid with RedZone?

posts.title: How many ads do NFL fans avoid with RedZone?
posts.text:
How many ads do NFL fans avoid with RedZone? Thank you, RedZone. Post to Facebook How many ads do NFL fans avoid with RedZone? Thank you, RedZone.  //usat.ly/2fWaj6b   Join the Nation's Conversation   How many ads do NFL fans avoid with RedZone? Steven Ruiz , USATODAY 1:22 p.m. EST November 15, 2016 
(Photo: for USA TODAY) 
Here's one opinion every football fan in America can agree on: The NFL RedZone channel is pretty awesome. 
If your favorite team isn't playing, RedZone is the best way watch football on Sundays. Not only do you get to check in on games around the country, but, more importantly, you also miss out on all those annoying commercials. And there are a lot of them. 
According to Exstreamist.com , the RedZone channel helps NFL fans avoid nearly 40 hours of commercials per season: 
We did some calculations and learned that RedZone subscribers are spared from 2,210 minutes of commercials every NFL season, about 37 hours, or 1.5 days. 
The average NFL game has 63 minutes of advertisements 
NFL RedZone broadcasts two blocks of games each Sunday 
63 minutes * 2 time blocks of games * 17 weeks of football = 1.5 days of commercials 
Those numbers are based on a study by the Wall Street Journal that estimated a typical NFL broadcast features 65 minutes of commercials and only 11 minutes of game time. 
Those are shocking numbers. But, thanks to RedZone, we can avoid all of those advertisements and take in all that sweet game action. Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/2fWaj6b Most Popular

thread.title: Facebook: Take The Money And Run
thread.title_full: Facebook: Take The Money And Run

posts.title: Facebook: Take The Money And Run
posts.text:
Send Message Summary 
While Facebook has been doing a great job at monetizing assets over the past year, there are limits to how much the company can milk users. 
Also, user growth has probably reached a critical peek in markets like the U.S., where almost all internet users are registered Facebook users. 
Given how expensive the stock is, I think that Facebook will eventually follow the path of Twitter and Pandora . "There is no great genius without some touch of madness" - Aristotle Facebook's (NASDAQ: FB ) recent Q3 results were not received with fanfare and fireworks from the market, sending the stock down significantly after earnings were announced on November 2. This despite the fact that total revenue and net income increased 56% and 165% respectively Y/Y. So what gives? To begin with FB is an extremely expensive stock . In my mind, no matter what the results were, eventually one of these quarters the stock was going to tumble, one way or another. Even after the current correction, FB has a market cap of about $335 billion, a trailing Price/Sales ratio of 13.5 and a P/E of about 44. For those of you who follow me, a Price/Sales ratio of above 6 is borderline bubble in my book, and so is a P/E of 44. Second, "user engagement" (the talk of the town) is reaching a critical point of saturation. MAUs (monthly active users) were 1.789 billion on average for the quarter, an increase of 16% year-over-year. However, does a 16% increase warrant FB being such an expensive stock? Not in my book. Sure revenue and profits are increasing faster than user growth, however as we now know from two other stocks that were once the talk of the town, user engagement is not the metric to bet on. Before I continue with FB, let me tell you the story of two stocks. Parallel Lives: Twitter - Pandora " Courage stands halfway between cowardice and rashness, one of which is a lack, the other an excess of courage " - Plutarch Let's start with Twitter (NYSE: TWTR ). Twitter was the talk of the town when it first went public. Everyone was fixated on user engagement and how revenue might increase, when and if the company found a way to monetize user engagement. However, while everyone was focused on user engagement, they forgot what they were paying for the stock. And when expectations of higher user engagement and higher EPS never fermented, suddenly everyone remembered how expensive TWTR was, and today TWTR is not very far from its all time lows. And personally, in the absence of someone making a bid for the company, I think it has more downside. My fair value target for TWTR is about $14 a share, with the possibility the stock reaching as low as $10 a share. (please consider: Twitter: Forget About User Engagement, This Is Still An Expensive Stock ). The second is Pandora (NYSE: P ), that I once considered to be the bubble of all bubbles (well almost). Similar to TWTR, everyone was fixated on the stock because of "user engagement". However when Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ) introduced its steaming music product (that today has about 17 million paid subscribers), suddenly increased user engagement evaporated (and has been in decline for several quarters), and then everyone remembered just how much of a bubble the stock was. Pandora reached as high as $40 a share. My fair value for the stock is about $8 a share, with the possibility the stock reaching as low as $5 (please consider: Why Pandora Fell 35% On Friday And Might Fall Even More ). Especially as far as Pandora is concerned, while user engagement is a bit lower, monetization is increasing at the best pace ever. In fact, Pandora is doing a great job at monetizing assets and increasing EPS. So why is the stock tanking? Because similar to FB, Pandora was such a bubble to begin with, that it made no difference. No matter how much EPS would increase, the stock was so far ahead of itself that it was still expensive. And because user engagement at Pandora is at a standstill, the market has understood that eventually increased monetization will also come at a standstill. You can not increase monetization indefinitely without a corresponding increase in user engagement also. So in other words, both TWTR and Pandora were valued based on assumptions of user engagement (current and future), rather than actual earnings. I think the market is pricing FB the same way. If so, then all we have to do is to find a crack in user engagement data before the market does (or before it becomes evident to all), and short the stock beforehand. Because I think what happened to Pandora and TWTR will also happen to FB. How long can user engagement keep increasing? The population of the U.S. and Canada is about 355 million people. According to FB, it has 178 million DAUs (daily active users) from both of these two countries. Click to enlarge This means that about 50% of the population of the U.S. and Canada use FB everyday. At the same time however, internet penetration in both of these countries is a little over 90%, according to multiple sources . So in other words, everyone except newborns are probably online, with a little over half of all Internet users on FB everyday. Please also note that, while DAUs in the U.S. and Canada are still increasing, the rate is in the single digits. So as a proxy for how many DAUs FB can eventually have globally, I will take the U.S. as an example and assume that about 50% of all internet users worldwide are potential daily FB users. Currently the world population is about 7.3 billion people. The current world internet penetration rate is about 50%. So FB's potential DAUs are about 50% of the current global population, which comes out to about 3.65 billion people. However, only about 50% of the online users in the U.S. and Canada use FB on a daily basis. So if we divide 3.65 billion people by 50%, then the Max amount of DAUs that FB might potentially have comes out to about 1.825 billion people. My first question is, based on the valuation of FB's stock, has this been discounted already? I think yes. In fact I think the market is running way ahead of itself. Because guess what folks, if we look at MAUs, then FB is maxed out already. Click to enlarge According to FB folks, about 1.8 billion people have logged in and used FB (desktop or mobile) ay least one a month last quarter. Please recall that the Max amount of people that currently can potentially use FB are about 1.825 billion people (based on my figures above, and based on U.S. and Canada usage data). So basically, even if all those registered people do not use FB on a daily basis, just about everyone on the planet who can potentially use FB is currently a registered user. How about potential future monetization? To be fair FB's revenue has been increasing far above user engagement data. As of the current quarter DAU's and MAUs increased by 17% and 16% respectively, but revenue increased by 56%. So management is doing a lot of right things. However remember that Pandora's revenue has also been rising, but that has not helped the stock at all. Click to enlarge However I think that over the next several quarters, revenue increase will come down by a lot. How so? If we look at the chart below, most of the increase in revenue per user has come from the U.S. and Canada. Click to enlarge If we look at the above data, while on a Y/Y basis FB had a very big increase in revenue per user from Q3'15, when we look at the Q/Q data since the last year, in most cases things are either at a stand still or revenue increase per user is in the single digits. My question is, will FB be able to repeat the almost 50% increase in revenue per user in the U.S. and Canada next year again? I do not know, however I would not bet on it. Please note that revenue per user went from $10.49 in Q3'15 to $15.65 in Q3'16. I don't know about you, but I do not think this will be repeated anytime soon. Something else interesting is revenue by geography. Click to enlarge About 50% of FB's revenue comes from the U.S. and Canada. And since about everyone in this region is already a registered FB user, I doubt very much that FB can continue to grow revenue by much in this region. Sure revenue per user could continue to increase -- even in the absence of engagement growth -- however there are limits how much money FB or any social media company can milk from each user. And while we do not know that limit, the fact that just about everyone who can possibly be a registered FB user already is, is not very comforting if I were a shareholder, given the valuation of FB. Please remember that FB makes $15.65 per user in the U.S. and Canada. Europe, which is the only other geographical region in which FB can expect to milk so much money from users, is only making $4.72 per user. And this figure has been at a standstill for several quarters. And if you think Asia or the rest of the world at some point in time will make for the company as much as the U.S. is making per user, I can tell you it will not happen in this lifetime. Simply put, the per capita income in these regions is too low for FB to be able to make the money they make in North America. Bottom line FB has been doing a very good job at monetizing assets over the past several quarters. However just about anyone that can become a registered user on the entire planet already is. While user growth will continue over the years, the increase will probably be in the low single digits. Revenue has been increasing higher than user growth, primarily because of assets such as Instagram. However please note this is a one time thing. Also, no matter how many other assets such as Instagram FB might have, you can only be at one place at a time. Users can not be on FB, and Instagram and other Social media sites at the same time. As such, at some point monetization growth will also come to a standstill. As such, FB in my eyes is a very expensive stock. Yes it might continue to grow, however growth over the next several quarters will not be what investors think, and the stock's trajectory will not be what investors have seen over the past years. The best case scenario I have for FB is to hover between $100 and $130 a share for a very long time. The worse being that the stock can correct at some point to $50 - $70 a share. However I would not short the stock yet. Sentiment for FB is still very high in investors eyes. I do not like getting in front of locomotive unless it comes to a full stop. However if you see technical weakness on a weekly scale, I would not say no to shorting the stock, if you are talented at shorting. In either case, if you have the stock, I think you should simply sell it. Yes you have made money all these years holding on to it, however there are limits to the market's generosity. And I think that over the next several quarters, investors will discover the market's generosity limits. Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. thread.section_title: NewsWhip Blog - Research on Content & Social Distribution
thread.title: How Often Do Top Publishers Post On Facebook?
thread.title_full: How Often Do Top Publishers Post On Facebook?

posts.author: newswhip.com
posts.title: How Often Do Top Publishers Post On Facebook?
posts.text:
How often should publishers be posting on Facebook? We look at the posting frequency of ten top publishers’ main Facebook pages, and look at the content formats that they tend to get more space.
How many Facebook posts is too many?
Many publishers wonder whether posting too often could adversely affect their visibility in news feeds. On the other hand, not posting enough can reduce engagement rates, and could cause missed opportunities around popular content. There’s also the consideration that the content needs to be different and appealing to different parts of the audience in order to achieve maximum reach and engagement.
So, how often are social publishing leaders posting on their pages, and what does the content output look like?
Using NewsWhip Analytics, we looked at the posting frequency on the top ten most engaged sites’ main Facebook pages over 24 hours on November 1.
Remember that here we were looking exclusively at the main Facebook pages of each of these publishers. So on November 1, the Daily Mail’s main Facebook page posted 99 times to their page, followed by Goal.com, with 72 total posts.
Beyond the top publishers, there’s a lot of discrepancy in posting frequency amongst these pages. BuzzFeed posted just 28 times to its vast audience on the day in question, with Fox News just slightly ahead, with 32 posts. Most of these publishers have worked to split their distribution out using multiple Facebook pages, each targeting a particular topic or subject, rather than presenting general content.
It’s interesting to note that not every piece of content produced by the website is posted to the main Facebook page. Each of these publishers use their main page as a strategic way of amplifying the content that’s most likely to do well on Facebook. For instance, the Huffington Post published 664 English language articles on the date in question, and only 37 of those ended up being linked to from the main Facebook page that day. Of the links that they did post, there was a lively mix of opinion pieces, news, and upbeat features.
One more thing to remember is that these numbers refer specifically to larger publishers producing large volumes of original content, rather than smaller pages, for whom a less frequent posting schedule is more suitable.
Next, we looked at how the posts broke down by content format. We split out the posts from the top ten pages by post format, to see if the pages were posting more of a particular type of content. Here’s what that post breakdown looked like for the ten pages over 24 hours:
Here we see that link posts (which include Instant Articles) make up the vast bulk of posts for the majority of pages. Links to owned web properties remain the number one most popular post format for publishers, who look to drive traffic to their own websites.
The Daily Mail is a notable exception, posting 51 videos, out of a total of 99 posts.
It’s also interesting to note the relative lack of image posts from the pages we surveyed. Of the ten pages, only ESPN and Goal.com, two sports publishers, were the only two pages to make use of the format. Our research has shown that image posts get higher average engagement rates than link posts.
How often to post?
So what’s the optimum posting frequency for publishers?
If you have a varied output of content, there seems to be no real limit on how often you should be posting. In reality however, your posting frequency will depend on analytics analysis, the content cycle on a particular day, and what your audience is responding to in real time. Instead of agonising about the frequency of your posts, focus on making sure that every post will have to compete with other elements in your audience’s news feeds.
To help make your post stand out, make sure that all the associated detail around the post is optimised with a strong image, good post copy, and critically, an interesting story for the reader.
Download NewsWhip’s guide to Facebook publishing for more best practice tips .
